NPC: Even if there is a lot of food, it will run out or perish. I assume you're not keen on starvation.

Choices.Player: Okay, let's leave.
I'll see what's outside first. I don't want to push you to your death.
I'm ambivalent. We'd just as well meet our end here.

NPC: You'll need to push me out of the door.

Choices.Player: All right, I'll push you
Too much effort. I'm leaving on my own.

NPC: What question!

Choices.Player: Why?
All right. Do you know anything about this room?

NPC: I can't remember my name. But there are worse things than forgetfulness. Had!

Choices.Player: Does my gait amuse you too?
What do you remember?

NPC: [The silence thickens.]

Choices.Player: [You do not break the silence.]
He's dead...

NPC: Possibly, yes. I can hear an asymmetry in your steps. You are obliged to walk. You do so as your circumstances permit. Being purely hypothetical, my gait is perfect.

Choices.Player: So you hear me limp! What's more, I can't sit without great discomfort.
What a load of dross!

NPC: The world is dross. I am of the world. What else could I speak?

Choices.Player: And what do you know of the world?
Your premise is flawed.

NPC: So I'm in a room... There was a metallic rumbling from behind some time before you arrived. The rest you know.

Choices.Player: What else did you hear before I got here?

NPC: My answering any question would have affirmed both. We might be closer to whatever it is we're supposed to do.

Choices.Player: Are you always this rude?
What if you were alive, but could not hear me?
You're right. I didn't think. What can you tell me about this room?

NPC: Our creator is sick! Disturbed! One bishop short of a diocese!

Choices.Player: That would explain the state of this place.
Not to mention unimaginative!

NPC: If you have the stomach for it, by all means kill me.

Choices.Player: Might be the only fun I have here.
No! I could never do that. I was... I was joking.
Putting you out of your misery is the humane thing to do,

NPC: Make it quick, then. Put an end to it!
Go on! But please don't draw out the act because it excites you. I would hate for the dregs of my suffering to be savoured someone like you.
Ha ha ha. Do you have anything useful to say?

Choices.Player: Yes.
No.

NPC: Come on then. Out with it!

Choices.Player: We can't stay here. We'll starve eventually.
We should eat something.

NPC: Do you have anything useless to say?

Choices.Player: Most of my vocabulary is useless here: Sky, fur, boats, joy, ecclesia... Compound interest!
I'll tell you what's useless: staying here and talking.

NPC: Pitch black? That would make no difference to me.

Choices.Player: Yes, but.it could be a precipice.
Would you like me to push you out of the door, then?

NPC: [He pauses for some time.] Yes.

Choices.Player: Are you able to feed yourself?
Why didn't you tell me you're hungry? There's a stove in here.
Has no one fed you? You must be starving!

NPC: Yes, I'm the only quadriplegic cook you're likely to meet.

Choices.Player: Really?
Hah! Okay, do you want me to try to cook you something?

NPC: No, you cretin! I'm tempted to ask you to cook me something, in the hope that you will manage to poison me.

Choices.Player: Why would I offer you so quick a way out? You can starve for all care!
How would gullibility make me a dangerous cook?
You're unkind, but I will try to cook you something.

NPC: Hunger is only a faint titillation now, promising much. That is to say, nothing.

Choices.Player: Don't be morbid, Let me cook you something!
I can think of quicker ways of killing you.
If you're that blase about eating, let's talk about something else.

NPC: I don't remember anyone feeding me.

Choices.Player: I'll make something to eat.
What do you remember?

NPC: Yes, unimaginative.

Choices.Player: Indeed. So do we eat or leave?

NPC: Oh by all means! Lets talk about something else.

Choices.Player: Like what?
Besides idle talk, the only option is leaving this room.

NPC: Why are you asking me? It was your idea.

Choices.Player: There's nothing left to say. We eat or we leave.
What did you do before you ended up here?

NPC: He's alive.

Choices.Player: You're alive?
Ah... yes. I'm Had. Nice to meet you.

NPC: No. This sentence is an improbable concatenation of the sounds naturally made by a decomposing body.

Choices.Player: What?
That's nice. My name's Had. Nice to meet you.

NPC: I don't remember hearing anything.

Choices.Player: Do you remember anything at all?

NPC: I remember nothing.

Choices.Player: That can't be true! You must remember something.
You don't remember a single person you've ever met?
Literally nothing?

NPC: You're right. There's definitely something here. I just needed to relax my definition of a thing.

Choices.Player: All right. I won't force you to discuss your life.
A thing? What about people?
There's an entire person there!

NPC: Not people but words. Words I've recalled again and again. Descendants of words once spoken. My many faux pas! Other than those the time I got the last word in with that braggart! And the blithe bruising words of that manipulatrix!

Choices.Player: You don't even remember your mother?
There must have been more people. What about the faux pas?
This could have even been a single manipulative braggart. At most two people! No one  in all of humanity you were close to?

NPC: All I know is what I have and in a sense it's worse than nothing. Nothing would be bliss compared to the traces of failure my brain bears.

Choices.Player: I could give you this nothingness.
"Traces of failure", You must remember more than you're letting on, nor can all of those memories be as bad as you let on.

NPC: What I am! Be is a form of the verb "am".

Choices.Player: Okay.
Spare me the grammar lesson!
[You remain silent.]

NPC: Joy! What a notion. We could be the ecclesia. I will found a religion. You my disciple.

Choices.Player: Tell me, beneficent one. Why are we in this room?
We could do worse.

NPC: A light bulb changes. From off to on and back again, for its entire life.

Choices.Player: There's more to you than a light bulb.
That's odd. I can see no switch for the lights in here.

NPC: The only thing I have ever had in common with others is a desire for my non-existence.

Choices.Player: You wouldn't talk like this if you hadn't been close to anyone.
I won't humour your wallowing any longer. I need to get out of here!
Okay. What about places and things?

NPC: In fact I do recall two things. She once fed me stewed rutabaga. I was obstinate, refused to swallow it. She would always exploit my weaknesses, having learned them before I had the sense to hide them.

Choices.Player: What weaknesses did she exploit?
I see. Funnily enough, there were several rutabagas in this room when I arrived.

NPC: Only when forced to state the obvious.

Choices.Player: If you're the only company this place has to offer, I'm going!

NPC: I might equally have been alive, able to hear you, but unwilling to answer. What does it matter?

Choices.Player: I just thought needless pedantry was normal here.
This achieves nothing. Do you know anything about this room?

NPC: If you're healthy, you should refrain from eating until you are not. If there's any much left, you may eat a little.

Choices.Player: Makes sense.

NPC: Yes. There's always cannibalism.

Choices.Player: Not yet! There may still be food. I can make some.
Let's get out of here before it comes to that.

NPC: What am I not missing?

Choices.Player: A room with grey walls and a bare concrete floor, whose only opening appears to lead into complete darkness. At the far end is a chest of drawers, some sort of stove, a sink and three chutes opening above wooden boxes containing food.
Just a dingy, artificially lit box with some poorly designed rubbish at the back.
A bare room with a few... appliances. There's an open door leading into a corridor.

NPC: And at the front?

Choices.Player: There is a doorway leading into what looks like a tunnel.
An opening leading into complete darkness.

NPC: Where might the tunnel lead, can you see any light?

Choices.Player: No, it just gets darker.
Yes, there's a faint light and what might be the rungs of a ladder.

NPC: Oh now... I can't think of a specific example.

Choices.Player: That's generally the way with exploitation. You feel it but you're sketchy about the details.
Why say all that , then?

NPC: Pop psychology! Drivel!

Choices.Player: Dreck!

NPC: The only relevant part of it my life – if that isn't putting it too strongly – is taking place as we speak.

Choices.Player: Let's attend to the matter at hand.
What are we supposed to do? What is there to talk about here?

NPC: Doggerel!

Choices.Player: Dross!

NPC: What do you mean by that?

Choices.Player: Kill you – put you out of your misery.
Nothing, never mind.

NPC: Oh dear, I was rather hoping you would offer to uethanise me, or at least dull the... not so much pain... tedium? No, dulling tedium would only magnify it.

Choices.Player: I'd rather magnify pain. Take my time. It will become just another kind of tedium.

NPC: Are you Serious? As long as you get the job done sooner or later.

Choices.Player: Yes
No, You called my bluff.

NPC: Disappointing. What now?

Choices.Player: There should be food here.
I think we should leave here. We'll starve otherwise.

NPC: Perhaps you could see what's down the corridor, or make us something to eat.

Choices.Player: I lied about the corridor. The door leads into complete darkness. I can't see anything at all outside.
Too much effort. I'll see about food, though; I'm a bit peckish.

NPC: [Sighs] Well, you could still make something to eat.

Choices.Player: Very well, I'll make some food.
We'll run out of food eventually. We'll leave regardless.

NPC: I can't remember the last time I ate.

Choices.Player: I didn't say I'd make anything for you!
I'll cook you something.

NPC: I can't help in that regard. All I recall before your voice is clanking metal and rumbling.

Choices.Player: We're in a room. There's an exit on one side and a rudimentary kitchen on the other. There appears to be food.
There's two options here. Eat the food lying in boxes, or take the only exit. Neither looks inviting.

NPC: I'm hungry.

Choices.Player: OK, I'll try to find some food.
Shut up!

NPC: Tell me when the food is ready.

Choices.Player: I'll let you know.
I'm not making any food.

NPC: Every time I left a place, I would think "there is nothing for me here".

Choices.Player: [You do not speak.]
Okay.
I'm sure this is interesting, but I think we should address the situation at hand.

NPC: Never mind.

Choices.Player: You're mad! I need to find a way out of here.
Good, let's talk about our situation.

NPC: Very well. Were are we? What are our options?

Choices.Player: We're in a room. There's an exit on one side and some kind of rudimentary kitchen on the other.
We can try to eat the food or leave via the only door. Neither looks inviting.

NPC: Then it's simple: We eat or leave.

Choices.Player: Are you hungry, I can try to make something for us to eat.
Let's leave. There's nothing to do here.
I'm not sure where the exit leads. It's completely dark outside.

NPC: Have you been outside yet? Did you find anything?

Choices.Player: It's just pitch black. My feet could find no purchase out there. It could be a sheer drop.
It seems like some kind of tunnel. I could feel a faint rush of air coming at me, so there must be a way out.

NPC: Then there's the question of states of mind. There are numerous differences between our sensoria. I feel hunger less. Would a day more of solitude even register in my mind?

Choices.Player: It's hard to say.
This might be simpler if we agree on whether starvation, or starvation combined with solitude, is worse?

NPC: Get out of my earshot.

Choices.Player: Sorry – changed my mind. I want to take you with me.
I'm going – just wanted to get one last look at your feeble body.

NPC: Are we out of the room yet? I can still hear the buzzing.

Choices.Player: Don't worry we'll leave soon.
Yes, we left a while ago. We're in a different room now.

NPC: Have we left the room yet?

Choices.Player: Not yet. I've got a few  things to do.
Yes, we're going now.

NPC: Let's get out of this room. There's nothing for us here.

Choices.Player: All right, I'll push you out.

NPC: Death is a certainty in here; it's merely a possibility out there. I have clung too fiercely to certainty my entire life and look how I ended up!

Choices.Player: Then we both go!

NPC: Why are you still here?

Choices.Player: I'm leaving!

NPC: What could possibly detain you in this room? Go!

Choices.Player: To be honest, I'm afraid the door leads to a sheer drop.
I'm going!

NPC: [The man is silent and still.]

Choices.Player: Can you hear me? Are you alive?
Hello.
[You smile] Hi! I'm Had, who are you?
[You say nothing.]

NPC: [He remains unmoving and doesn't utter a word.]

Choices.Player: Um... Hi.
[You hold your tongue.]

NPC: Who said that? I can't see a thing.

Choices.Player: You're not missing much?
I'm Had. Who are you?

NPC: [The man laughs.]

Choices.Player: [You  join in laughing.]
What's funny?

NPC: Perhaps. Perhaps life is nature's only error. Perhaps you ought to kill me.

Choices.Player: Do you really want that?

NPC: Leave the way you came!

Choices.Player: I'm not sure how I got here.
There's one opening. I can't see where it leads.

NPC: A ladder? How did I get down here? Never mind. Could you carry me up? I can't be much more than bone now. In any case a quick death is preferable to a slow one.

Choices.Player: Okay, let's leave this place.

NPC: Doesn't it? Well, I'm willing to take the chance.

Choices.Player: I suppose we'll eventually starve here. Let's go.

NPC: [The man is not breathing.]
Give me something to eat so we meet our end together.

Choices.Player: All right....
On second thought, we're leaving!
How would we ensure that we pass at the same time. Within an hour of each other, even.

NPC: Well, use your powers of deduction.

Choices.Player: There's one opening, leading into what appears to be a tunnel.
There's a door to this room, though it's too dark to see where it leads.

NPC: Leave me to starve.

Choices.Player: No, I'll make you some food.
As you wish.

NPC: Leave me to starve.

Choices.Player: No, I'll make you something to eat.
As you wish.

NPC: I have general ideas of things: conveyor belts, jars, tabulating machines. All that has substance to me now is something like an ocean.

Choices.Player: An ocean?
You're mad! I'm finding a way out of here. I can't listen to this.

NPC: I wasn't aware of its push and pull, its ebb and flow. I wanted strange, foolish things. Acted senselessly. Caused pain. It's hard to see nature of your sight. Now this ocean is all I know with any clarity. It was almost still before you got here.

Choices.Player: Not sure I follow the metaphor.
I've heard enough of this gibberish. I'm going!

NPC: Here's another! A neglected dog, tormented by bored children. Its master ignores this. One day, it tears its master's throat out.

Choices.Player: You're mad.
I get it. Don't let people under your skin.

NPC: Your suffering.

Choices.Player: Can you laugh at your own suffering?

NPC: I used to, quite a lot, but even the best jokes wear thin.

Choices.Player: Can you recall any of this suffering?

NPC: [The man continues laughing.]

Choices.Player: [You continue laughing with him.]

NPC: What of it?

Choices.Player: Never mind. I'm leaving.
I think I'll go the same way if I stay here.

NPC: Try to find out. I'm not yet willing to take just any door. Things can always be worse.

Choices.Player: I suppose so. Let's stay here. Are you hungry? There's food here... of sorts.
Actually, now that I look closer, the door seems to lead into a tunnel.
Worse! Have you... Well of course you haven't seen this place. You're not missing much, if that's any consolation

NPC: And the state of me!

Choices.Player: Oh, enough about you!
Cruelty incarnate this creator.

NPC: I must be hungry, because the thought of a rutabaga does not turn my stomach.

Choices.Player: Good. I'll cook some.
There's no more rutabaga.

NPC: Say what?

Choices.Player: Oh, I'm sick of this. I wish I could get out of here.
You said your mother exploited your weakness before you had the sense to hide it.

NPC: Solitude can be good or bad. If we tried we could think of situation in which starvation is good, but this gets us nowhere.

Choices.Player: If it's inevitable we'll starve, let's not eat.

NPC: Don't have a skin. Bleed freely. Hope they lock you up.

Choices.Player: Did they lock you up?
I think I've heard enough. I'm going.

NPC: She was sometimes close, and sometimes less so. She moved, you see. Gracefully. And I, more or less stationary, was at the mercy of her movement.

Choices.Player: So you've always needed a wheelchair?

NPC: No, I did move, though never with ease. I moved better, or at least more, when I saw her. Now, I haven't seen or moved in a long time, but I still play it out in my head, like an etiolated plant imagining springtime.

Choices.Player: What do you play out?

NPC: Her moment. Farther and closer, in exquisite arcs...I know this is foolish, but...

Choices.Player: But?
Any specific examples?

NPC: Life never suffocated the fool in me. Perhaps I had been able to move more.. But I still nurture it.

Choices.Player: Speaking of foolishness, this talk achieves nothing.
Perhaps I could help you put and end to it.

NPC: What would you rather talk about?

Choices.Player: Food, perhaps. We need to eat.
Leaving this place. We can't stay.

NPC: Yes. I'll admit it. That half-cocked syllogism left a bad taste in my mouth. A person does no better to abuse logic here than use it.

Choices.Player: So you'd rather starve and talk gibberish! Logic has a use here.
This is nonsense. Undernourished brain, perhaps. Are you hungry?

NPC: Tripe!

Choices.Player: Excrement!

NPC: Gibberish!

Choices.Player: Gumpf!

NPC: No others. I spent my life perfecting the solitary faux pas.

Choices.Player: Can you give me an example?
This is getting absurd. I'm leaving.

NPC: I held a belief about which I was uncertain. About the contents of another's mind.

Choices.Player: My puny intellect can't cope. I'm leaving!
[You remain silent.]

NPC: True. I wonder who is exploited here? You or me?

Choices.Player: Both of us. There is some other agency at work here.
Me, if I choose to keep you alive.

NPC: Only a truly despicable person would commit such a thing to writing!

Choices.Player: I can't argue with that.
And you're not such a person?

NPC: Despicable, yes. But to be truly despicable would require that my nature fit the crude logic of truth and falsity...

Choices.Player: Please stop. The first was bad enough.
[You stay silent.]

NPC: Good. Where were we?

Choices.Player: Before the all that business with your memory, I think we'd just met.
I told you my name.

NPC: Indeed, the entirety of nature would need to be amenable to logic. That is to say the world.

Choices.Player: I've  had enough of this!
[You hold your tongue.]

NPC: If the world were indeed composed of states of affairs, however numerous. These expressible in some language, however arcane and artificial.

Choices.Player: Stop!
[You do not utter a word.]

NPC: It could be said that I am truly such a despicable person.

Choices.Player: That was the last of it I hope!
[You remain silent.]

NPC: [The man does not speak.]

Choices.Player: You're finished?
[You do not speak.]

NPC: Must be, but I can't remember what.

Choices.Player: Lucky you.
That you're a despicable person!

NPC: I think I can summarise by saying that I'm despicable, but not truly so.

Choices.Player: You certainly can.
I'm making some food. Do you want any?

NPC: [He is silent.]

Choices.Player: I'm going.
[You don't break the silence.]

NPC: [The man is silent.]

Choices.Player: So that was it?
[You are silent.]

NPC: In that case if there was enough to sustain us for four times longer, it would be worse to ignore the craving. Twice and we'd do better.

Choices.Player: As you suggested there's more of me left. I'll outlast you on catabolism alone.

NPC: I feel better now! I think I know where we stand.

Choices.Player: Are you happy?
I wish I knew.

NPC: Pedantry is my only talent. Leave off or we'll fall out.

Choices.Player: Talent! Do you even have a postgraduate degree? What have you had published? Has anyone willingly listened to you with the aim of improving their knowledge?
If the only vacancy is for a pupil. I'm not staying here.

NPC: Let's not get ahead of ourselves! "Better" might have been a push.

Choices.Player: [You sigh.] Well where do we stand?
I think we got a little excited. Let's get back to the matter at hand.

NPC: Neither of us will be able to tell when you've lost it.

Choices.Player: Then I need to leave!
We should go. I can get you help.

NPC: This could even be my cell.

Choices.Player: Let's escape!
I could be your jailor

NPC: Yes let's leave. How do we get out?

Choices.Player: There's only one exit: a doorway.
There's an opening in the back of this room, but I can't see where it leads.

NPC: Servant, more like! I'm couldn't escape if I wanted to.

Choices.Player: I'm no one's servant. Good bye!
It's the only thing that makes sense. Do you want some food?

NPC: Yes. I'm hungry.

Choices.Player: OK, I'll try to find some food.
No, I'm no one's cook.

NPC: Don't talk to me.
No. That doesn't sit right, does it? All words result from decay. Each one brings us closer to falling into a disorder.

Choices.Player: [You are silent.]
[You cough.] I'm Had, nice to meet you.

NPC: This would be more proper. A string of disturbances within my bloated bowels played my soft palate like a wind instrument.

Choices.Player: [You clear your throat.] Hello, I'm Had.
[You remain silent..]

NPC: Thus producing a semblance of speech!

Choices.Player: Yes. Of course. My name's Had, by the way. Nice to meet you.
[You don't utter a word.]

NPC: [He says nothing.]

Choices.Player: You should be careful with that kind of talk. You know what people say about first impressions. Anyway, my name's Had.
[You hold your tongue.]

NPC: Well?

Choices.Player: That was disgusting.
That was interesting. My name's had. It's a pleasure...

NPC: What's so unpalatable about a human corpse? It's almost guaranteed to act ethically. It's the living who disgusted me.

Choices.Player: Tell me about these disgusting people.
I can't listen to any more of this. I'm out of here!

NPC: [He does not speak.]

Choices.Player: [You say nothing.]
What's there to talk about in this room. We should go.

NPC: I know my reasoning is flawed. I don't know enough to reason better. An education was beyond my means, or so I surmise.

Choices.Player: You didn't go to school?
Can't you tell I'm bored. I'm leaving here at once.

NPC: I couldn't say. There's a gulf in my memory that stretches from early childhood to late adulthood.

Choices.Player: I'm surprised you can distinguish between the two.
I'm sorry to hear that.

NPC: I tend to assume the happy memories are childhood ones.

Choices.Player: A good rule of thumb.
As much as I enjoy playing the psychotherapist, we need to take stock of this situation.

NPC: It could be worse. You don't know what I've forgotten.

Choices.Player: Nor do you.
Fair.

NPC: This is tiresome.

Choices.Player: Yes. This place is stultifying. Can we leave?
Perhaps some food will break the tedium.

NPC: What I am keen to know is whether I'll die here.

Choices.Player: There is an exit, though I can't see where it leads.
There is food.

NPC: Let's talk about you, Had.

Choices.Player: That wasn't what I meant.
Not much to say, really. I've always been caught up in one thing or another. No time of autobiography.

NPC: What did you mean?

Choices.Player: I meant the practicalities. What do we do? We're in some sort of rudimentary kitchen, with one exit.

NPC: Nothing left to say about either of us. What about this place?

Choices.Player: This room is dingy and artificially lit,  with some poorly designed rubbish at the back.
We're in a bare room with a few... appliances. There's an open door leading into a corridor.

NPC: Leaving one person here to starve was one thing. But company!

Choices.Player: Perhaps one of us should prologue their life. The other starve in solitude.
I'll spare you my company. I'm going.

NPC: Cook anything. I don't care.

Choices.Player: Fine.
You can starve for all I care. I'm going.

NPC: And what is that?

Choices.Player: Assuming we both want to live. The food here will perish, as will we. There is an exit that could lead us to outlive the food by more than a month.

NPC: Your premise is flawed.

Choices.Player: You want to die? I'm going without you.

NPC: I sold graphics cards for data centres. How about you?

Choices.Player: I bought hardware for data centres.

NPC: How serendipitous!

Choices.Player: If only there were computers here.

NPC: If only.

Choices.Player: Maybe there are computers on the other side of that door. I'm still not sure what's out there.

NPC: To my detriment.

Choices.Player: Don't be ridiculous!
I can't argue with that.

NPC: A light bulb is useful. It doesn't complain.

Choices.Player: Then stop complaining. Be like the bulb you admire.

NPC: Is there a surface for my wheelchair?

Choices.Player: I'll check.

NPC: Let me know whether the tunel is passable.

Choices.Player: I've checked and it's flat. Similar to the floor in here.
There's a lot of rubble out there. I don't think you'll get through.

NPC: Could you not carry me?

Choices.Player: No, I can't.
I can try.

NPC: Why? Fate? Causality?  Fear of intimacy?

Choices.Player: Closer to the first two. It's beyond me.

NPC: I know the feeling. Goodbye.

Choices.Player: Sorry to leave you like this.
I  wouldn't want to be you right now.

NPC: You should leave while you can.
I think I'm still in my chair.

Choices.Player: Sorry, I can't carry you.

NPC: You assume that being alive is in some way advantageous to me.

Choices.Player: Life seems to provide you with a bottomless reservoir of self-pity.
Well then I'm the exploiter.  I can do whatever I want to you. I can let you starve. You're defenceless.

NPC: I see what you mean – though it's hard to think what could be gained from putting us here.

Choices.Player: It needn't make sense. The trouble begins when matter starts wanting things.
We could be a form of entertainment.

NPC: Have you tested the darkness with your foot?

Choices.Player: Yes. I could find no purchase. It could be a metre deep. It could be a kilometre.

NPC: Why didn't the buzzing stop?

Choices.Player: There were lights along the way.

NPC: You said it was dark in the passage.

Choices.Player: [You say nothing.]
We haven't left the first room.

NPC: Have the decency to lie convincingly.

Choices.Player: I'm sorry.

NPC: [The man is silent.]

Choices.Player: [You hold your tongue.]
We're still in the first room.

NPC: [The man does not speak.]

Choices.Player: We haven't left the first room.
[You remain silent.]

NPC: I though I grew out of that nonsense!

Choices.Player: We all resent our parents.

NPC: I meant weakness you cretin! Weakness!

Choices.Player: You don't strike me as the strongest of people.

NPC: [The man is silent.]

Choices.Player: No offence.
[You don not speak.]

NPC: [The man remains silent.]

Choices.Player: Hello!
[You hold your tongue.]

NPC: [His silence thickens.]

Choices.Player: Sorry!
[You keep quiet.]

NPC: Yes. You are a serf. You sow the seeds of misery. I accumulate most of the yield and give you just enough to survive. It's the natural order.

Choices.Player: What?
What If I revolt?
I think I prefer it this way.

NPC: Bollocks! You can see what's under your feet. Describe it to me.

Choices.Player: The floor is concrete, bare in the middle with streaks of dirt near the walls. What gets me is what's behind the these walls.
I'd rather not.

NPC: Amid bad prose and bric-a-brac. That rally of words! Reminded me of my tennis days!

Choices.Player: The rally! I see now.
What?

NPC: [He utters half a syllable then stops.]

Choices.Player: The pipes that end in the corner. They must start somewhere.
There's an opening. It must lead somewhere.

NPC: If I had such an advantage, I'd cling to it too.

Choices.Player: I'm not one to cling! The floor is concrete if you must know.
Now I'll leave you to you ignorance!
There's nothing work hearing about here. Let's leave this place.

NPC: Superstition!

Choices.Player: I don't need this! I'm going to find where they come from!
Do you want come with me? We'll see who's superstitious.

NPC: What do you mean "what"? You were part of it.

Choices.Player: Understand what?
They came crashing into my awareness. Seemed right for the moment.

NPC: You wouldn't be the the first living thing to bring about to such a... jolt to my nervous system! And not comprehend the part you played.

Choices.Player: I don't even want to understand that.
That's vile. I'm going.

NPC: Let's talk about something else.

Choices.Player: There's more facile chatter or silence. Or we can talk about leaving here.
There's food here. Are you hungry.

NPC: And the walls?

Choices.Player: Painted white. Composition unknown.

NPC: Miraculous.

Choices.Player: Not a word I thought I'd hear here.
Wonderful. Now let's attend to the dross.

NPC: Trotted out under worse circumstances no doubt.

Choices.Player: And what are our circumstances?

NPC: Does what it is now here even qualify as circumstances? You're better equipped to answer anyway.

Choices.Player: We're in a room. There's an exit on one side and a rudimentary kitchen on the other. There appears to be food.
This room affords us two options. Eat the food lying in boxes, or take the only exit. Neither looks inviting.

NPC: You're right. One should never underestimate the perversity of agency

Choices.Player: It's true. I have half a mind to leave you here to rot.
This is facilitating, but we should deal with the matter at hand.

NPC: It's no skin off my nose.

Choices.Player: Okay, I'm leaving.
In that case I'll stay. Sustain you. Are you hungry?

NPC: Yes. Let's not given them the satisfaction. What's the least entertaining thing we can do?

Choices.Player: We should leave here at once.
Let's starve in silence.

NPC: A splendid idea

Choices.Player: That settles it.
Sorry, I can't do that. Let's leave here.

NPC: The time I'd been brusque. I could feel her eyes boring into my back. I knew she wouldn't leave until I turned my chair. So I did, eighteen degrees at a time.

Choices.Player: [You are silent.]
I can't listen to this! We need to attend to the matter at hand.

NPC: After that I remember staring at her bare ankles. Not her face. Nothing else. I don't know what she did or when she left. Shame carved a hole in my memory. When I try to push though, it is as thought I've caught hold of my own viscera.

Choices.Player: I wouldn't force you to relive that. Lets talk about something else.
Ach! What's wrong with you?

NPC: There are two sources of uncertainty there: thinking of another, and thinking of the future. You'd do better to restrict your thoughts to the present and yourself.

Choices.Player: I'm hungry. I'm making some food.
Right now I want to get our of this room!

NPC: Can I have some?

Choices.Player: Yes.
No.

NPC: I'll stop when my heart does.

Choices.Player: I can expedite this.
So be it. Let's talk about something else.

NPC: The lights are making that awful buzzing?

Choices.Player: They must be.
No, I don't think so.

NPC: Where does this leave us?

Choices.Player: In a room. There's an exit on one side and a rudimentary kitchen on the other. There appears to be food.
With two options: Eat the food lying in boxes, or take the only exit. Neither looks inviting.

NPC: Good. What were we talking about before light bulbs?

Choices.Player: I'd just introduced myself.
I can't remember.

NPC: Can you find a way to end the buzzing?

Choices.Player: I can try.
No.

NPC: I hope the buzzing stops soon.

Choices.Player: I'm still looking for a way.
I can't find a way to stop it.

NPC: I can still hear the buzzing.

Choices.Player: I haven't stopped it yet. Sorry.
There's no way of stopping it.

NPC: I've tolerated it up until now. Why not until the end?

Choices.Player: You're assuming it ends here. We should leave this place.
It's a shame, but we have more important matters to attend to.

NPC: Oh yes! always need to get that out of the way when I first meet people.

Choices.Player: Now that we're past formalities, let's deal with the situation in which we find ourselves.
I think the only thing left to discuss is when we leave this room.

NPC: Any what's your name?

Choices.Player: Had.
It's not important.

NPC: What is?

Choices.Player: The room we're in:. There's an exit on one side and a rudimentary kitchen on the other. There appears to be food.
Our options in this room. We either eat the food lying in boxes, or take the only exit. Neither looks inviting.

NPC: [He is silent.]

Choices.Player: I think our only option is to leave this place.
[You do not speak.]

NPC: Do your worst.

Choices.Player: I'll let hunger take you.
Starvation is too slow. I'll do it myself.
I'll leave this room. To hell with you!

NPC: I should probably eat.

Choices.Player: I'll cook you something.

NPC: What now?

Choices.Player: I don't know.
Let's deal with the matter at hand.

NPC: [He remains silent.]

Choices.Player: I'm sick of this. I'm leaving!
[You hold your tongue.]

NPC: I'm content to sit here and rot.

Choices.Player: I'm leaving this place!
I'm not letting you. I'm leaving and you're coming with me.

NPC: Debatable but you're right. I would do well to value my being.

Choices.Player: Your being?
[You don't speak.]

NPC: But that's not right. Is it? What I'd give to "be"...  All this leaden moment seems to do is sink.

Choices.Player: This is all very abstract. You like to rationalise, don't you?  What's really wrong?
It may seem to sink now, but being can change. It is change.

NPC: Can I finish?

Choices.Player: Yes.
No.

NPC: The door? You must have come from somewhere!

Choices.Player: There's a doorway. A rectangular opening. Pitch black outside.

NPC: Anything else of note?

Choices.Player: Enough! I'm not giving you a full inventory of this room.
Left to right: cupboard; gas hob; sink; three metal chutes opening above boxes – these contain celery, cornflour and rutabagas.

NPC: The ceiling?

Choices.Player: Grey, possibly plaster!

NPC: Good. Any light fittings?

Choices.Player: Two. Likely fluorescent. Buzzing incessantly.
You're relentless! I'm not answering that.

NPC: Allow a blind man this one indulgence.

Choices.Player: No!
Oh all right.

NPC: Excellent!

Choices.Player: I hope all that was useful.
Well that's that!

NPC: It wasn't in the slightest but I've always acquired knowledge for its own sake.

Choices.Player: That's it. I'm leaving!
Now we've got that out of the way, we can talk about the matter at hand.

NPC: One last indulgence.

Choices.Player: Oh all right.
Not a chance!

NPC: Who knows, maybe my parents were addicts. Selling sex and things they stole in front of me.

Choices.Player: You remember this?

NPC: No. Just exercising my imagination.

Choices.Player: I think it's time we attend to reality.

NPC: A few things I'm sure, even when I could see and walk. I don't remember.

Choices.Player: Oh dear. I'm sorry, I don't know what I meant by that.
So you're a headcase as well... I'm out of here!

NPC: It's hardly ambiguous. The way I acted. There was something broken in my head! Something missing! I'm almost glad you came out and said it.

Choices.Player: I... I don't know what to say. Let's talk about something else.
You gain nothing by beating yourself up about something you can't change. Let's try to deal with the matter at hand.

NPC: You can have all the misery to yourself.

Choices.Player: If misery is currency here, I want all of it. I'll kill anyone in my way!
[You laugh.] This is amusing but let's deal with the matter at hand.

NPC: Then I thought that a good God, a loving God, wouldn't plonk an erroneous thought in my skull. I must, therefore, have been right.

Choices.Player: That certainly is bad.
Have you written these aphorisms down?

NPC: That was horrible! What did you just shovel that into my mouth. Did you even cook it?

Choices.Player: No. You should be grateful to get anything!
Sorry, I'll cook it next time.

NPC: Grateful? You overestimate the value I place on my ongoing existence.

Choices.Player: All life is valuable.
All right, perhaps I should put an end to it.

NPC: Next time? Wonderful! Monotony, then death.

Choices.Player: What do you suggest instead?
Then we should leave!

NPC: Thanks. I'm sure I've eaten worse muck.

Choices.Player: Okay, what's the worst thing you've eaten?
You'd better get used to it. There's nothing here to improve it.

NPC: Probably an insect. As a child I naively thought they were named after their contents: butterflies, mealworms, cockroaches.

Choices.Player: What would a cockroach contain?
Can we talk about something else?

NPC: Oh, I was just being obscene.

Choices.Player: Oh, right. I'm not sure what to say now.
I suppose you're allowed to paedophilic references to your self.

NPC: It's one of life's few guiltless pleasures.

Choices.Player: What disturbs me is that I don't even know whether you're serious.
Oh dear. Let's change the subject.

NPC: Wonderful! Monotony – if not decline – then death.

Choices.Player: What do you suggest instead?
Then we should leave!

NPC: Serious about what?

Choices.Player: You were... Never mind. I'm leaving!
You were... sexualising your childhood self.

NPC: Oh yes, It's one of life's few guiltless pleasures.

Choices.Player: You said that already.

NPC: Said what?

Choices.Player: You were talking inappropriately about your childhood.
Enough of this! Let's deal with the matter at hand.

NPC: [The man is silent.]

Choices.Player: [You don't speak.]
Lets, let's deal with the matter at hand.

NPC: Good. Make me some food. Make it as vile as possible.

Choices.Player: Very well.
Surely starvation would be worse.

NPC: [The man remains silent.]

Choices.Player: [.You hold your tongue.]
Right, I'm leaving!

NPC: I can think of nothing worse than drawing my life out with bland food, can you?

Choices.Player: Fair point, I'll make something insipid.
This is ridiculous! The only sane option is to leave here.

NPC: I'm not sure whether that was mush or ash you fed me.

Choices.Player: Why aren't you sure?
Yes, I overcooked it... Sorry.

NPC: Can't taste much anymore.

Choices.Player: You're lucky.
What can you do?

NPC: I can hear quite well.

Choices.Player: You've been in this room longer than me. What did you hear?
And you have me for company! Life is cruel.

NPC: Yes, It's a useless sense here. I wish I could see though.

Choices.Player: I'm not sure you're missing much,
Have you always been blind?

NPC: I saw once, but not sharply.

Choices.Player: Do you remember what it was like to see?

NPC: It is indeed. It's a mark of my cowardice and nothing else that I've lived this long.

Choices.Player: So you want to die.
This bitterness achieves nothing. Let's deal with this situation.

NPC: Yes, I want to die.

Choices.Player: I... Can't we talk about something else?
Given the cruelty of out situation, killing you is the kindest thing thing I can do.
I was hoping you'd say that.

NPC: Yes, I remember her.

Choices.Player: Her?

NPC: After leaving scores of places, even an intellect as feeble as mine began to make out a pattern.

Choices.Player: [You are silent.]
This talk achieves nothing. Let's deal with out situation!
I've heard enough. I'm out of here!
Right.

NPC: Lichen, for example, establishes some sort of footing on even the most barren of rock. Whatever organisms – and... agglomerations of culture! – have coalesced to form me, add up to something with less of a place in the world than a coalition of fungi and bacteria – or at least, to a thing capable of thinking this to be the case. Which is hardly better.

Choices.Player: Perhaps lichen ruminates on the past.
What?
